title: When Job Applicants Should—and Shouldn’t—Wear Luxury Brands
text:
Luxury brands are taken as signals that you have less warmth and kindness, so avoid them for interviews if a job requires those traits.

Let’s say you’re hiring a publicist for your new nightclub. One candidate carries a Louis Vuitton handbag; another, an unidentifiable bag. You might feel the candidate with the luxury-brand bag is better connected and more able to promote the business. Now imagine you’re interviewing kindergarten teachers for your school. Which candidate will better care for youngsters?

A large body of research has shown that luxury brands convey wealth, high social standing and power. Status is a central core of luxury-goods marketing. But two researchers at Northwestern University’s Kellogg School of Management recently asked if wearing luxury brands can ever backfire. That is, might there be a social cost to flashing a Gucci or Burberry logo?

It turns out there can be a social cost to luxury goods, particularly when it comes to first impressions of the sort created during job interviews. Research suggests that job seekers should carefully consider the messages that a Rolex watch, logo leather goods and other luxury products convey in a particular setting. When a job requires trustworthiness, empathy, likability or kindness, luxury goods might best be left behind.

“The brands we choose to adorn ourselves with signal rank,” says Derek Rucker, a Kellogg marketing professor who conducted the study, which was published in the journal Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, with Ph.D. candidate Chris Cannon. However, high status isn’t desirable for every job. “There’s a dark side,” he says. “You have to ask, what am I wearing and in front of whom?”

Status vs. warmth

To explore these complex reactions, Dr. Rucker and Mr. Cannon devised four experiments—three conducted with paid subjects who participated online, and one in which Northwestern undergrads came to a lab to participate. In one experiment, 120 male and female participants were shown identical photos of a man in a T-shirt. In one case the T-shirt had no logo. In others, the shirt had a Gucci logo (the researchers chose Gucci because it ranks among the top luxury brands globally).

The participants were then asked to rate the man on various characteristics such as social status, class, warmth and caring. Participants rated the Gucci-logo man lower for traits like warmth, trustworthiness and kindness but as having higher status. They also felt that the Gucci man was trying hard to manage their impression of him.

The researchers then replicated the experiment with 120 different men and women, this time using identical photos of a woman with a handbag—one unmarked, the other a Burberry bag with its trademark plaid pattern. Similarly, participants rated the woman with the Burberry bag to have higher status but lower warmth.

Delving further, 115 undergraduates were asked to review questionnaires filled out by candidates for a business simulation, and to select the candidate with whom they would most like to work. The questionnaires were identical except that some mentioned luxury-brand names—Prada, Rolex, Burberry, Porsche—in the candidates’ answers.

It turned out that the students preferred to work with the luxury-brand candidate for a publicity job, but picked the nonluxury-brand candidate for the human-resources job. “People were choosing based on whether status or warmth were necessary” for the job, Mr. Cannon says.

What’s more, it seems people ascribe motives to others who wear luxury brands. Participants who believed the brands were flashed to influence how they felt about the person—what the researchers called “impression management”—felt most strongly that those candidates lacked warmth, trustworthiness and kindness.

When impressions count

These findings may back up research at the University of Michigan in 2018 that found that status symbols such as luxury goods can block the formation of new friendships. It turned out that many people found the status-signaling to be a turnoff.

These findings counter a wide body of belief and research into the benefits of luxury goods and wardrobes. Numerous studies have explored the status-defining powers of brands. Dutch researchers Rob Nelissen and Marijn Meijers in 2011 found that luxury brands elicited preferential treatment and even financial benefits in a series of experiments published in the journal Evolution and Human Behavior.

The latest results caused the researchers to reconsider their own appearances. Dr. Rucker says he thought, “When I go in the classroom, how do my students perceive what I wear?” He began to consider his own impression management, such as explaining why he was wearing a nice watch, so students wouldn’t assume he was trying to impress them.

When wearing expensive products into situations where impressions count, he suggests considering whether signaling high status will be a benefit or a hindrance.

“In hiring, these symbols can be misinterpreted,” Dr. Rucker says. “These symbols have power. There’s a dark side that’s pretty complex.”

Ms. Binkley is a writer in Los Angeles. She can be reached at reports@wsj.com.
description: People who wear luxury brands are judged as having higher status, but less warmth and kindness, new research shows.
